book_title: Venture Deals: Be Smarter than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist
overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practitioner’s guide to the language, mechanics, and politics of venture capital financings. The book opens by demystifying the venture ecosystem — profiling entrepreneurs, angels, syndicates, venture capitalists and their internal hierarchies, lawyers, and mentors — and shows how those human incentives and roles shape the form and substance of financing documents. Using historical anecdotes (like the DEC investment) the authors show how a simple price-and-ownership note evolved into today’s multi-page term sheet. From that foundation the book advances a central thesis: virtually every negotiation in a venture financing boils down to two things — economics (who owns what) and control (who can influence or veto major actions).

From that overarching frame the authors walk the reader clause-by-clause through a modern term sheet. They explain valuation mechanics, the dilution impact of option pools, liquidation preferences (including participating preferred), conversion mechanics, vesting, information and registration rights, ROFRs, co-sale and restrictive transfer provisions, protective provisions and board composition, and the common tradeoffs each side cares about. Interleaved throughout are entrepreneur-perspective sidebars that translate legal and economic mechanics into tactical negotiating advice and red flags to watch for (for example, insist on spelling out employment terms before agreeing to a no-shop clause).

The book then turns to the practical arithmetic and alternative instruments that drive financings: how to build and interpret a capitalization table so you can understand dilution and price-per-share implications; the pros and cons of convertible debt (discounts, caps, maturity, conversion triggers) and newer SAFE/KISS-style instruments; and the legal pitfalls every founder must master (employment agreements, IP assignment, and especially the 83(b) election). In each section the tone is pragmatic: the authors favor transparency, preparedness, precision in cap-table math, and an understanding that a signed term sheet is often only the start of closing the deal.

Finally, the authors broaden the gaze beyond individual deals to the startup ecosystem, presenting the Boulder Thesis on how startup communities flourish: entrepreneur-led initiatives, long-term leadership commitment, inclusiveness, and recurring hands-on activities. Throughout the book the emphasis is on practical empowerment — giving founders the vocabulary, mathematical tools, negotiation tactics, and legal touchpoints they need to be effective partners in raising capital, preserving upside, and building enduring companies.
key_themes: Economics vs. Control as the core of term-sheet negotiation
Demystifying VC jargon and structures through practitioner-focused explanation
Founders’ empowerment: cap-table fluency and tactical negotiation
Transparency and information rights balanced with confidentiality
Legal preparedness to avoid irreversible mistakes (e.g., 83(b), employment/IP issues)
Practical community and ecosystem building (the Boulder Thesis)
learning_objectives: Identify the key players in venture financing and understand their incentives and leverage
Analyze a term sheet by separating the economics (valuation, dilution, liquidation preferences) from the control terms (protective provisions, board rights, voting)
Build and manipulate cap tables to quantify dilution, option-pool effects, and price-per-share
Evaluate and negotiate convertible instruments (notes, caps, discounts, SAFEs) and their implications for future rounds
Recognize legal landmines (employment agreements, IP assignment, 83(b) elections) and take steps to mitigate them
Adopt negotiation tactics and entrepreneur-focused best practices (no-shop handling, information rights, ROFRs, founder activity clauses)
Apply community-building principles to strengthen local startup ecosystems

chapter_summaries.chapter_title: Venture Deals
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 1, “The Players,” maps the human ecosystem that drives venture financing. Building on the Introduction’s framing of the term sheet as the blending of economics and control, this chapter profiles each participant — the entrepreneur, the venture capitalist, angel investors, syndicates, lawyers, and mentors — describing their roles, incentives, and typical behavior during a fundraising process. It also introduces practical nomenclature for financing rounds (seed, Series A, B, etc.) and distinguishes types of venture firms (early-stage, growth, corporate, strategic) so the reader can anticipate how different investors will approach deal terms, risk, and governance.

The chapter’s practical value is that it translates abstract deal mechanics into people-driven dynamics: who negotiates the term sheet, who leads the round, how syndication changes leverage, and why the lawyer and mentor matter beyond paperwork and advice. Understanding these players clarifies why certain economic and control provisions (covered in later chapters) get proposed, resisted, or traded off — for example, why a lead VC pushes for protective provisions and board seats, why angels focus on valuation and dilution, and how syndicates influence speed and closing. By grounding the mechanics in motivations and process, the chapter prepares the reader for the tactical guidance in subsequent chapters on raising capital, drafting term sheets, and negotiating specific provisions.
key_concepts: Types of venture firms (early-stage, growth, corporate VC)
main_topics: Roles and motivations of each participant in a deal

Practical roles of lawyers and mentors in fundraising

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

<!-- PageNumber="xiii" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="xiv Foreword" -->

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals: Be Smarter than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist, Third Edition By Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson Copyright @ 2016 by Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson" -->

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 5 moves from the high-level framing of the venture ecosystem and the history of the term sheet (introduced in earlier chapters) into a practical, organized overview of what actually matters when a VC term sheet is negotiated. The authors reduce the negotiation to two overriding concerns—economics (the investor's return in liquidation or IPO) and control (the mechanisms that let investors influence or veto company actions)—and walk through the principal economic and control provisions that populate modern term sheets. Using concrete examples and entrepreneur-focused commentary, the chapter explains how price interacts with related items (option pool sizing, warrants, liquidation preferences, pay-to-play, vesting, exercise periods, and antidilution protections) and why lawyers often spend time on clauses that matter less than these core tradeoffs.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Insist on spelling out key terms prior to a signed term sheet if it has a no-shop
clause in it. A VC who won't spell out key employment terms at the beginning
is a big red flag.

There are plenty of other wacky conditions-if you can dream it
up, it has probably been done. Just make sure to look carefully at this
paragraph and remember that you don't necessarily have a deal just
because you've signed a term sheet.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 6 shifts from the history and anatomy of term sheets (Chapter 4) and the two overriding negotiation concerns of economics and control (Chapter 5) to a practical handbook voice from the entrepreneur’s perspective. The chapter issues a clear caution: if a term sheet contains a no‑shop or exclusivity clause, insist that critical operational terms — especially employment-related details like title, responsibilities, compensation, vesting, and severance — be spelled out before you sign. Because a no‑shop restricts your ability to continue shopping the deal, vague or deferred promises can trap you without leverage.

The chapter also flags behavioral red lights and odd contract terms. A VC who refuses to document key employment terms early is a major warning signal. It reminds founders that virtually any unusual condition has likely been tried by someone, so read every paragraph closely; signing a term sheet is not the same as having a closed, enforceable deal. The practical upshot is that entrepreneurs must pay attention not only to price and protective provisions (the subjects of prior chapters) but also to timing and clarity of operational commitments before exclusivity takes effect.
main_topics: How no‑shop clauses affect negotiation timing
Importance of spelling out employment and operational terms early
Vigilance for odd clauses and behavioral red flags

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you care about information rights for your shareholders, you are nuts. You
should run a transparent organization as much as possible in the twenty-first
century. If you can't commit to sending your shareholders a budget and financial
statements, you shouldn't take on outside investors. If you are of the paranoid
mindset (which I generally applaud), feel free to insist on a strict confidentiality
clause to accompany your information rights.
chapter_summaries.summary: Building on the book’s earlier mapping of the venture ecosystem and the anatomy of term sheets, this chapter adopts the entrepreneur’s point of view and makes a simple, practical case about information rights: embrace transparency. Whereas earlier chapters explained how term sheets grew to capture economic and control levers, here the authors argue that information rights—requests for budgets, financials, and regular reporting—are a normal and healthy part of outside investment. If you cannot commit to that level of openness, the advice is blunt: don’t take outside investors. For founders who worry about leaks or proprietary data, the pragmatic compromise is to accept reasonable information rights but pair them with a strict confidentiality clause.

practical commitment to reporting
balancing openness and confidentiality
how information rights function as a control mechanism

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Don't focus much energy on registration rights. This is more about upside. The
world is good if you're going public.
chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter adopts the entrepreneur’s vantage point and reframes term‑sheet negotiation as a forward‑looking exercise in preserving and maximizing upside. Building on the anatomy of term sheets and the two overriding concerns of economics and control, it argues that entrepreneurs should evaluate every clause by asking how it affects the company’s ability to go public and capture value in an IPO. Practically, that means prioritizing ownership, dilution mechanics, liquidation preferences, and governance arrangements that keep the company attractive to public markets and aligned with long‑term value creation.

The chapter also tempers attention to certain investor protections—most notably registration rights—by pointing out that if an IPO is the likely outcome, those provisions matter less than the economic and control structures that determine how much of the upside founders and employees retain. It reiterates the earlier counsel to embrace transparency around performance and governance (tying back to information rights), and to negotiate with an eye toward future financing and exit paths rather than short‑term permit/restrict fights. Overall, the entrepreneur’s job is to preserve optionality for a public exit while aligning investor incentives to support that path.
main_topics: prioritizing terms that preserve IPO upside
evaluating term sheets through exit scenarios
how economics and control affect public market readiness
when registration rights matter (and when they don’t)
maintaining transparency to enable exit

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

The right of first refusal is not a big deal, and in some cases it's good for you.
But make sure you define what a major investor is and give this only to them. At
a minimum, you can make sure that shareholders get this right only if they play
in subsequent rounds.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 9 takes the entrepreneur’s practical view on the restriction on sales clause—commonly called the right of first refusal (ROFR) on common stock—and explains why it is generally acceptable and often beneficial to the company and its stakeholders. It describes typical term‑sheet language, notes that the company can exercise the ROFR or assign it to investors, and recommends placing the clause in the bylaws (one centralized location) rather than scattering it across option agreements and plans. The chapter also recounts the historical shift: early venture practice often prevented founders from selling until investors liquidated, but longer liquidity timelines and the rise of secondary markets have increased private‑stock sales and prompted more nuanced discussion of ROFRs.

Building on earlier chapters’ mapping of term sheets and negotiation priorities, the chapter argues that entrepreneurs should embrace ROFRs as a control tool that helps manage the shareholder base, protect corporate governance, and keep the company aware of pending transfers—particularly important as regulators like the SEC scrutinize private shareholder rules. It adds pragmatic guidance: define who counts as a “major investor” and consider granting ROFR rights only to those investors (or only to shareholders who continue to participate in subsequent financing rounds), so the right protects long‑term stakeholders rather than transient buyers.

Placement of ROFR in bylaws vs. option agreements

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

A proprietary information and inventions agreement clause is good for the com-
pany. You should have all employees, including founders, sign something like
this before you do an outside venture financing. If someone on the team needs
a specific carve-out for work in progress that is unrelated to the business, you
and your investors should be willing to grant it.
chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter reinforces the entrepreneur’s pragmatic stance toward two kinds of protective provisions: proprietary information and inventions agreements (PIIAs) and co‑sale/transfer restrictions. Building on prior chapters’ mapping of the venture ecosystem and the anatomy of term sheets, it argues that requiring all employees (including founders) to sign a PIIA before outside financing is standard, sensible practice to protect company IP, while also recommending reasonable carve‑outs for truly unrelated outside work in progress. The chapter treats PIIAs as a routine, company‑protective document that entrepreneurs should embrace rather than resist, provided narrow exceptions are granted where warranted.

On transfer restrictions, the chapter accepts that eliminating a co‑sale or co‑sale‑style clause is unlikely but counsels entrepreneurs to negotiate practical floors and exceptions. Small, bona fide liquidity events—such as a founder selling a bit of stock to buy a house—should not be unduly blocked by VCs. A right of first refusal (ROFR) that uses a bona fide outside offer as the purchase price is a reasonable investor protection; an all‑consuming exclusion that effectively prevents any transfer is not. The tone is pragmatic: preserve upside and investor confidence by accepting common protections, but push for sensible, entrepreneur‑friendly limits where possible.
main_topics: Requiring PIIAs before financing
Negotiating carve‑outs for unrelated founder work
Practical negotiation of co‑sale clauses
ROFR mechanics and acceptable valuation triggers
Balancing investor protections with founder flexibility

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you can't agree to a founders' activities clause, don't look for professional
VC financing. Or you can negotiate a very specific carve-out, and expect other
consequences in your terms (e.g., vesting and IP rights).
chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 11 continues the entrepreneur‑centric thread from the prior chapters by turning to several often‑recurring, but generally negotiable, term‑sheet items: the founders’ activities clause (flagged in the chapter title as effectively a deal breaker if you cannot accept it), the no‑shop agreement, indemnification of directors and investors, and assignment provisions. Building on the anatomy of term sheets and the entrepreneur’s focus on preserving upside (Chapter 8), the chapter stresses practical tradeoffs: if a founders’ activities restriction is unacceptable, professional VC financing is the wrong channel unless you can negotiate a tightly specific carve‑out—and be prepared for knock‑on effects such as additional vesting or IP assignment demands. The chapter then explains that a no‑shop is largely a time‑limited, symbolic covenant (typically 30–60 days) that signals mutual commitment to close; entrepreneurs should insist on a fixed short period and use the interval to test whether the VC is serious and able to follow through. Real‑world examples show that reputation and character often matter more than rigid enforcement of no‑shop clauses.

Testing VC commitment and reputational risk
Assignment clause (VCs' ability to transfer interests)
Protection against assignment loopholes (transferee bound to same agreements)
main_topics: Practical negotiation stance for entrepreneurs
How and when to accept or limit no‑shop clauses
Why indemnification is standard and the role of D&O insurance
Permitted assignment and safeguards for the company
Interplay between contractual terms and the people/reputation involved

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. If you do this math, you'll
Example Capitalization Table
Class Shares Preferred Price Valuation Percentage
Founders 2,000,000 A
Employee pool B 20%
Venture investors C D $5,000,000 33.33%
Total E D $15,000,000 100%
see that (2 million + 857,081) * $3.50 = $9,999,783.50. Oops, we are off by $216.50, which represents 62 shares (well, 61.857 shares). While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. That's why most cap tables have two addi- tional significant digits (or fractional shares)-the rounding to the nearest share doesn't happen during intermediate steps but only at the very end. As the entrepreneur, you shouldn't blindly rely on legal counsel to generate these documents. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. Although some get it right, it's your responsibility as the entrepreneur to make sure you understand your cap table. This will be especially helpful at times when you want to expand the employee option pool and you are eloquent in front of your board of directors explaining the ramifications.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 12 shifts from clause-by-clause term sheet analysis to the practical mechanics of the capitalization table (cap table), which every term sheet includes in summary form. Using a concrete example (2,000,000 founder shares, $10M pre-money, $5M new money → $15M post-money), the chapter shows how to translate dollar valuations and percentage targets into actual share counts and price per share. It demonstrates the common wrinkle of an investor-required option pool expressed on a post-money basis (20% in the example), and how that requirement dilutes founders’ ownership even though the headline valuation stays the same. The worked math produces the total shares outstanding, the option-pool share count, the number of preferred shares issued to the VC, and the implied preferred price per share ($3.50 in the example), and it flags the practical need for fractional shares/extra precision to avoid small but material rounding errors.

Building on earlier chapters that explain the economics and negotiable terms of a financing, the chapter stresses that the cap table is not just bookkeeping: it is the numerical embodiment of term-sheet tradeoffs (valuation, option pools, investor ownership) and drives future economics and control. Founders are warned not to defer cap-table math entirely to lawyers (who may be weak at the arithmetic) and to be fluent in the calculations themselves—especially when discussing option-pool sizing, dilution, and subsequent financings with investors and the board.
main_topics: How a summary cap table appears in a term sheet
Converting valuations and investment amounts into shares and price-per-share
Impact of a post-money option pool on founder dilution
Importance of precision and fractional shares in cap-table calculations
Why founders must understand and verify cap tables (not just rely on counsel)

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 13 shifts from term‑sheet line‑item analysis and cap‑table mechanics (Chapters 10–12) to a different financing instrument commonly used at the seed stage: convertible debt (notes). Building on prior discussions about why parties sometimes defer pricing, the chapter explains convertible debt as a loan that typically converts into the next equity round at a discounted price (or via a valuation cap), and it walks through the practical mechanics and negotiation levers entrepreneurs should watch. It emphasizes entrepreneur‑centric tactics (set a reasonable time horizon or forced conversion, prefer a floor on conversion valuation rather than a ceiling) and warns that debt character brings legal and leverage differences compared with equity (holders of outstanding debt have stronger enforcement/remedies and can create awkward power dynamics).

The chapter unpacks the key economic and legal terms: discount, valuation cap, interest, maturity/qualified financing thresholds, automatic versus optional conversion, amendment/majority‑holder mechanics, warrants and their tax/accounting impact (original issue discount), and the SAFE/KISS alternatives. It connects these features to earlier material: how caps and discounts affect future term‑sheet negotiations and cap‑table dilution, how conversion mechanics interact with liquidation preferences and voting/protective provisions discussed previously, and why entrepreneurs should be careful disclosing seed terms to prospective VCs. The chapter closes by contrasting early‑stage (seed/bridge) and late‑stage uses of notes and describes real‑world dangers (notes that fail to convert or permit a small group of noteholders outsized control), while introducing SAFEs as a non‑debt alternative that trades some protections and simplicity for other investor disadvantages.

valuation caps and their market effects
conversion mechanics and timing (qualified financing)
warrants: structure, exercise, merger treatment, OID
differences between convertible notes and SAFEs
risks of debt: holder leverage and amendment thresholds

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Legal Things Every Entrepreneur Should Know

T.
here are a few legal issues that we've seen consistently become
hurdles for entrepreneurs and their lawyers. While in some cases
they will simply be a hassle to clean up in a financing or an exit,
they often have meaningful financial implications for the company
and, in the worst case, can seriously damage the value of your busi-
ness. We aren't your lawyers or giving you legal advice here (our
lawyers made us write that), but we encourage you to understand
these issues rather than just assume that your lawyer got them right.

If you want to read the best book ever written on legal issues that
face entrepreneurs, get the book The Entrepreneur's Guide to Business
Law, Fourth Edition, by Constance Bagley and Craig Dauchy (South-
Western, 2012). It is written for entrepreneurs, not lawyers, so it's easily
digestible and is the best legal resource we know for entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 14 shifts from term‑sheet mechanics and financing instruments (Chapters 10–13) to practical legal issues every entrepreneur must understand because they routinely become costly hurdles in financings and exits. The chapter focuses on three durable areas: employment law (the most common source of lawsuits), choice of corporate entity (C Corp vs S Corp vs LLC) and when each makes sense for fundraising and taxation, and the critical 83(b) election that, if missed within 30 days of a stock grant, can permanently alter your tax outcome. The authors emphasize that these are not abstract legalities but often irrevocable business decisions — a missed 83(b) or a poorly drafted employment arrangement can materially reduce founder and employee economics or jeopardize a transaction.

The practical thrust is preparedness: make hires “at‑will” in offer letters (or consciously prebake severance if desired), have a good employment lawyer you can call fast, choose your corporate form with fundraising plans in mind (VCs typically require a C Corp), and file 83(b) elections promptly when receiving restricted stock. The chapter also points entrepreneurs to useful resources (Bagley & Dauchy), provides a glossary of key terms, and connects to the appendices (sample term sheets and LOIs) so readers can see how these legal points show up in real documents.

VC fundraising requirements and multi‑class stock
Irrevocable legal mistakes (tax and transaction risks)

Choosing the right corporate structure for fundraising and tax

chapter_summaries.summary: This chapter steps back from the deal‑level mechanics covered earlier (term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and routine legal hurdles) and examines the broader question of why startup activity clusters in certain places. After summarizing classic explanations from economics, sociology, and geography (notably Marshallian externalities and the "spikiness" of innovation), the author advances a practical, experience‑based alternative called the Boulder Thesis. The Boulder Thesis argues that vibrant startup communities require four interlocking elements: entrepreneurs leading the effort, leaders who make a long‑term (20+ year) commitment, an inclusive posture that welcomes anyone who wants to participate, and recurring, hands‑on activities that engage the entire entrepreneurial stack.
main_topics: Historical frameworks for startup clusters
The Boulder Thesis and its four components
The need for sustained leadership through economic cycles
Practical community activities that produce engagement
Accepting failure and iterating community experiments
